Description: A terminal from a piece of furniture: formed of a piece of sheet copper beaten out into a bell-shape, with the wide end closed by a separate copper disc. The object has been restored from fragments and is heavily corroded. It still contains traces of decayed wood.
Curator's comments: This kind of terminal was used on chairs and beds, and was sometimes made of ivory as an alternative to copper-cased wood, (W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' II' (London, 1954), 44, no.105; 45, nos. 165-7 and pl.XXVII). In Saqqara, tomb 3471, copper-cased terminals were discovered in situ on a wooden bed-frame (W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' I (Cairo, 1949), 57 and pl.11A). The same kind of terminal occurs on the bed of Hetepheres, but in this case covered with gold (H. S. Baker, 'Furniture in the Ancient World' (London, 1966), 47, fig. 35.) For parallels, see W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' II' (London, 1954), 39, no. 25; 40, no. 42; 45. no. 176; 54, no. 303 and pls.XXVI-XXVII; W. B. Emery, 'Excavations at Saqqara, 1937-1938 : Hor-aha' (Cairo, 1939), 64, no. 349; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pls.XXXV, 83; XLI, 87; E. Amélineau, ‘Les Nouvelles Fouilles d’Abydos’ I (1895-6), pl.IX. See also the representations of terminals on furniture, J. E. Quibell, 'Excavations at Saqqara, 1911-12 : the tomb of Hesy' (Cairo, 1913), pls.XIX-XX; H. S. Baker, 'Furniture in the Ancient World' (London, 1966), 31-2, figs. 18-20. Bibliography: W. B. Emery, 'Great tombs of the First Dynasty; excavations at Sakkara' III (London, 1958), 50, no. 4.
